e_subtitle: Select the highlighted team members to listen to the team's conversation

launchConclusion.e_text:
The painter's tape encountered some issues post-Launch, but you worked with the team to identify these issues as soon as they arose.

You were also able to apply redesigns and address manufacturing drift. After these interventions, the business performance of the tape increased and it became a true 3M business success!

conclusion.e_text:
Discovering an unanticipated failure mode post-Launch speaks to how important it is to conduct robust testing of the product earlier in the commercialization process.

The team determines the best intervention for the problem is to issue strict guidance for the transportation and storage of the painter's tape. This will minimize the chances of failed product arriving at stores located in geographic markets with hot climates.

If negative customer or end-user feedback is encountered post-Launch, you must determine the root cause of the feedback.

Begin by investigating: “Are we manufacturing the product to specifications?”

If the answer to this question is yes, you can then move onto other questions. The next appropriate question set would be: “Is the design correct?” If the design is still correct, you and the team may wish to investigate if the market is correct for the product, or if the product is the right fit for 3M.

You work with the team to identify a specification issue with adhesion and address it to improve the tape’s performance.

It is possible that a part of the VOC goes completely unidentified and because of this, its impact will be unanticipated. Carefully evaluating the VOC early in the process can help reduce this risk.

If an important customer need is missed, you must collaborate with the team on a solution and document all steps taken. Thorough documentation helps the product continue to be successful and also informs future products, contributing to Product and Process Understanding (PPU).

Remember you must also amplify the VOC as changes are made to help ensure the product will be right.

questions.e_prompt:
The team responds to the finding of an unanticipated failure mode: The tape’s adhesive is oozing out the side of the roll when transported in high temperature areas.

Which of the following would have been most helpful in preventing this if it had happened earlier in the commercialization process?

feedback.e_text: This unanticipated failure mode may have been identified earlier in the process if there was more testing to evaluate extreme conditions, like temperature.

choices.e_text: Including extreme environmental conditions as a failure mode in the Product FMEA

feedback.e_title: This could limit the product’s success.
feedback.e_text: Adjusting the FMEA to address environmental conditions would be more suited as a reaction to this failure mode, rather than a way to identify or prevent it. A change to packaging may give customers warning, but it doesn’t help prevent the problem.

While more customer field testing may have given the team more information, it would not necessarily have helped to uncover a failure mode for transportation of the tape in extreme temperatures. The more helpful intervention would have been more product testing to evaluate extreme conditions.

questions.e_prompt:
You notice a theme in customer feedback: The tape’s adhesive is not sticking to certain surfaces strongly enough.

Manufacturing wonders: “Is there a drift from the Manufacturing Control Plan?”

Which of the following should you investigate?

correct.e_text: All of the available options are possible root causes of the discovery that the tape's adhesive is not meeting customer expectations. All of them should be explored to diagnose the issue and begin developing solutions.

incorrect.e_text: All of the available options are possible root causes of the discovery that the tape's adhesive is not meeting customer expectations. All of them should be explored to diagnose the issue and begin developing solutions.

choices.e_text: Are customers using the product the way it is intended to be used?
Is the manufacture of the product still within product specifications?
Was the tape designed correctly in the first place?

questions.e_prompt:
The team reviews customer feedback and identifies a major theme: Customers are disappointed in the color of the tape.

Which of the following is the primary reason why this outcome has occurred?

choices.e_text: Color is a failure mode for the product

feedback.e_text: This is tricky. Color would be a failure mode if manufacturing variation led to a failure (such as color fading). In this case, the customer need is that there be a choice of what color the tape is. Color treated as a failure mode does not adequately explain this situation. Instead, it appears that color was not a customer need that was identified to begin with.

choices.e_text: Color was not accurately translated from a customer need into the product design

feedback.e_text: This is tricky. If you observe the DQM, color is not present as an identified important customer need. Therefore, it would not have had an opportunity to be mistranslated. The primary reason for the current situation appears to be that color was not a customer need identified to begin with.

choices.e_text: Color was not a customer need that was identified

feedback.e_text: Color was not one of the primary customer needs identified during Build Business Case by the team as they completed the DQM. Somehow, color has emerged as an important part of the VOC that was not only not translated, but not identified from the onset.

questions.e_prompt:
Color has been added to the DQM and other tools. The team works to revise the tape and bring it back to the market with new color specifications.

What is the most important thing for you to facilitate as the Quality team member?

feedback.e_text: While there may be important lessons learned from this post-Launch redesign, the most important thing to do as the Quality focus team member is to ensure that all relevant project documentation is updated with post-Launch changes.

choices.e_text: Ensuring all relevant project documentation is updated with post-Launch changes

feedback.e_text:
Documentation is key throughout all phases in the commercialization process. This is especially true for large shifts in product design.

Robust documentation of all of the changes made to the product and process is the most important step to take here.
The most important thing to do as the Quality team member after this event is to ensure all relevant project documentation is updated with post-Launch changes.

badges.text: Congratulations! Your efforts in translating customer needs into design specifications has earned you the Customer Advocate Badge!
badges.caption: Customer Advocate

badges.text: Congratulations! You have inspected a potential failure mode in the product/process by examining testing performance, uncovering a necessary redesign. You’ve earned the Test Evaluator Badge!
badges.caption: Test Evaluator Badge

badges.text: Excellent work! You’ve taken all the steps necessary after the painting tape underwent a necessary redesign, all while ensuring that the VOC remained amplified in the process. Your diligence has earned you the Robust Designer Badge!
badges.caption: Robust Designer Badge

badges.text: Fantastic! You worked with a primary supplier for the materials for the painting tape to ensure that issues with their quality system were addressed. This has earned you the Systems Master Badge!
badges.caption: Systems Master Badge

badges.text: Congratulations! You collaborated with the team to ensure that the VOC was correctly retranslated, and you’ve worked to document the process so that the painting tape can continue to be successful into its market life cycle. Your thorough efforts have earned you the Documentation Champion Badge!
badges.caption: Documentation Champion Badge
